page.title: 06RAILWAY
page.content: An Act of Parliament in 1845 allowed the Trent Valley Railway Company to build a line that would enable the most direct route from Manchester to London( by-passing Birmingham).Land was secured from William Stratford Dugdale,M.P. and in 1856 the station and twin tracks were built.Coal,wool,grain and cattle were collected by Red Lion omnibus.The railway became the second largest employer in town.An increase to four tracks and further buildings occurred in the early 1900's,later to be demolished in the 1960's.The line joined the London,Midland and Scottish Railway in 1923 which was later taken over by British Rail in 1947.The line was electrified in 1964 but owing to declining traffic the station became an unmanned halt in 1972.The station building has Listed Building Status and was restored in 1984.
